ygData.subject: Seeded-CPPNs: Injecting Complex Geometric Patterns into CPPNs for Further Evolution
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, I m pleased to announce the following new paper on the Seeded-CPPN Technique : Upload Any Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geometric

From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Seeded-CPPNs: Injecting Complex Geometric Patterns into CPPNs for Further Evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=TN8Qv--c-ovb49Fwv877mG29DyFD-UwDG-UUlwvacCnQeh_agJOU
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_C0B1F688-FF4B-4974-A962-C6B146DE87B3
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello all,

I'm pleased to announce the following new paper on the "Seeded-=
CPPN Technique":

Upload Any Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geomet=
ric Patterns into CPPNs for Further Evolution.
Clune, Chen, & Lipson. 2013.=
 Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation.
http://jeffc=
lune.com/publications/2013-Clune-SeededCPPN-CEC.pdf

In this paper we discu=
ss how to inject arbitrary patterns into a CPPN to *start* evolution, so yo=
u can further evolve any 3D object with the CPPN encoding. What I find most=
 exciting is that this technology could in principle work for any CPPN-enco=
ded phenotype, such as neural networks. Many details remain to be worked ou=
t, but this technique may make it possible to inject a mouse or human conne=
ctome into a CPPN and then further evolve it. The technique also enables en=
tirely new types of studies into evolvability, as explained in the abstract=
 and text. 

I'm also happy to finally have a paper with appearances by Sup=
er Mario and the Kool-Aid man! The figures are pretty fun. :0)

Abstract=97=
Ongoing, rapid advances in three-dimensional (3D) printing technology are m=
aking it inexpensive for lay people to manufacture 3D objects. However, the=
 lack of tools to help non- technical users design interesting, complex obj=
ects represents a significant barrier preventing the public from benefiting=
 from 3D printers. Previous work has shown that an evolutionary algorithm w=
ith a generative encoding based on developmental biology=96a compositional =
pattern-producing network (CPPN)=96can automate the design of interesting 3=
D shapes, but users collectively had to start each act of creation from a r=
andom object, making it difficult to evolve preconceived target shapes. In =
this paper, we describe how to modify that algorithm to allow the further e=
volution of any uploaded shape. The technical insight is to inject the dist=
ance to the surface of the object as an input to the CPPN. We show that thi=
s seeded-CPPN technique reproduces the original shape to an arbitrary resol=
ution, yet enables morphing the shape in interesting, complex ways. This te=
chnology also raises the possibility of two new, important types of science=
: (1) It could work equally well for CPPN-encoded neural networks, meaning =
neural wiring diagrams from nature, such as the mouse or human connectome, =
could be injected into a neural network and further evolved via the CPPN en=
coding. (2) The technique could be generalized to recreate any CPPN phenoty=
pe, but substituting a flat CPPN representation for the rich, originally ev=
olved one. Any evolvability extant in the original CPPN genome can be asses=
sed by comparing the two, a project we take first steps toward in this pape=
r. Overall, this paper introduces a method that will enable non-technical u=
sers to modify complex, existing 3D shapes and opens new types of scientifi=
c inquiry that can catalyze research on bio-inspired artificial intelligenc=
e and the evolvability benefits of generative encodings.

Congratulations t=
o undergraduate Anthony Chen (cc'ed) on his first publication!

Please let =
me know if you have any reactions or questions. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune=


Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@uwyo=
.edu
jeffclune.com


--Apple-Mail=_C0B1F688-FF4B-4974-A962-C6B146DE87B3
